user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_FdSet_ConvertOut_Impl:
```c
static void OS_FdSet_ConvertOut_Impl(fd_set *OS_set, OS_FdSet *OSAL_set)
{
    size_t       offset;
    size_t       bit;
    osal_index_t id;
    uint8        objids;
    int          osfd;

    for (offset = 0; offset < sizeof(OSAL_set->object_ids); ++offset)
    {
        objids = OSAL_set->object_ids[offset];
        bit    = 0;
        while (objids != 0)
        {
            id = OSAL_INDEX_C((offset * 8) + bit);
            if ((objids & 0x01) != 0 && id < OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES)
            {
                osfd = OS_impl_filehandle_table[id].fd;
                if (osfd < 0 || !FD_ISSET(osfd, OS_set))
                {
                    OSAL_set->object_ids[offset] &= ~(1 << bit);
                }
            }
            ++bit;
            objids >>= 1;
        }
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_FdSet_ConvertOut_Impl:
#define OSAL_INDEX_C(X) ((osal_index_t)(X))
...
typedef uint32 osal_index_t
...
#define OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES 50
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (osfd < 0 || !FD_ISSET(osfd, OS_set))
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated. The expression uses FD_ISSET(osfd, OS_set) which reads bits from the fd_set; it does not assign to OS_set nor modify the pointer itself. The code only reads OS_set (and later modifies OSAL_set->object_ids — modifying the object pointed to by a pointer parameter is permitted by MISRA 17.8), so no parameter is being modified in the shown fragment.
